document.docTitle: Heteropoda steineri Bayer & Jäger, 2009, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Heteropoda species from limestone caves in Laos (Araneae: Sparassidae: Heteropodinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Heteropoda species from limestone caves in Laos (Araneae: Sparassidae: Heteropodinae)

Note: Juveniles could readily be identified by means of reduced eyes and the absence of a colour pattern as in adult specimens.
Etymology. The specific name is given in honour of the cave scientist and friend Helmut Steiner, who collected the type material of this species; noun (name) in genitive case.

Diagnosis. Eyes exceptionally small in contrast to all other
Heteropoda species
known so far ( Fig. 114 ). dRTA of male palp broadest subdistally. Spines on palpal tibia exceptionally short ( Figs 29–30 , 42–43 ). Position of bulb not centrally in cymbium, but shifted a bit prolaterally ( Figs 30 , 43 ). Ventral flange of conductor turning prolaterally not before the basal third of conductor ( Figs 34 , 45 ). Sperm-duct more or less straight. Epigynal field wider than long (basal length/width <0,8) and anterior bands very narrow and in many cases not continuous but separated from epigynal field ( Figs 41 , 50 ). Median septum slightly longer than broad. Anterior, narrow part of septum between copulatory openings far less than half as broad as median, broadest part. Anterior part of internal duct system covering at least half of the length of posterior part ( Figs 37 , 47 ); anterior part wider than long ( Figs 37 , 47 ).

Prosoma length 8.3 – 9.7, prosoma width 7.2 – 8.2, anterior width of prosoma 3.4 – 3.9, opisthosoma length 8.8 – 11.1, opisthosoma width 3.9 – 5.5. Eyes: AME 0.28 – 0.31, ALE 0.37 – 0.44, PME 0.31, PLE 0.44 – 0.45, AME – AME 0.14, AME – ALE 0.08 – 0.14, PME – PME 0.33 – 0.39, PME – PLE 0.47 – 0.51, AME – PME 0.25 – 0.27, ALE – PLE 0.37 – 0.42, clypeus height at AME 0.77 – 0.78, clypeus height at ALE 0.67 – 0.69.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 29–41.
Heteropoda steineri
sp. nov.
from Khammouan (29–31, 33–35 ♂ holotype, PJ 2847; 32, 36–41 ♀ paratype, PJ 2846). 29–31 Left ♂ palp (29 prolateral; 30 ventral; 31 retrolateral); 32 Right ♀ palpal claw, prolateral; 33 RTA, ventral; 34 Bulb, ventral; 35–36 Right chelicera, ventral; 37 Vulva, dorsal; 38 Schematic course of internal duct system, dorsal; 39 Anterior part of internal duct system, frontal; 40–41 Epigyne (40 posterior, 41 ventral).

FIGURES 42–50.
Heteropoda steineri
sp. nov.
from Khammouan, variation of ♂ and ♀ copulatory organ (42–46 ♂ paratype, PJ 2853; 47–50 ♀ paratype, PJ 2854). 42–44 Left ♂ palp (42 prolateral, 43 ventral, 44 retrolateral); 45 Bulb, ventral; 46 RTA, ventral; 47 Vulva, dorsal; 48 Anterior part of internal duct system, frontal; 49 Schematic course of internal duct system, dorsal; 50 Epigyne, ventral.

subSubSection.paragraph: Colouration. Body uniformly coloured, pale light greyish-yellowish-brown without darker pattern ( ♀ , Fig. 113 ).

Prosoma length 7.8 – 11.0, prosoma width 6.9 – 8.8, anterior width of prosoma 3.4 – 5.0, opisthosoma length 8.8 – 13.8, opisthosoma width 4.7 – 9.0. Eyes: AME 0.30 – 0.32, ALE 0.38 – 0.45, PME 0.31 – 0.34, PLE 0.44 – 0.48, AME – AME 0.15 – 0.20, AME – ALE 0.09 – 0.12, PME – PME 0.35 – 0.46, PME – PLE 0.58 – 0.68, AME – PME 0.29 – 0.35, ALE – PLE 0.50 – 0.55, clypeus height at AME 0.92 – 1.03, clypeus height at ALE 0.85 – 0.87.
Colouration. As in male, but in some cases a bit paler ( Fig. 113 ).

Variation of copulatory organs. Basal part of dRTA of male pedipalp sometimes with transversely arranged grooves (n=1, Figs 44, 46 ). In some individuals distal part of dRTA differing in shape ( Fig. 46 ). Tegulum more or less strongly shifted prolaterally ( Figs 30 , 43 ). Number and length of spines on palpal tibia differing strongly ( Figs 29–31 , 42–44 ). Anterior bands of epigynal field with different numbers of gaps, sometimes without gaps. Anterior bands rarely relatively short (n=1). Vulva shape varying barely ( Figs 37 , 47 ).
